Posts.Content: Hi, just to give you all an update, i had the hickman line fitted in my neck/chest today.  the procedure took 15 mins but i was in the hospital 4 1/2 hours.  Good grieve, why do we have to wait so long to get something simple done.  No one mentioned that my face would be covered by the surgical sheets, probably it doesn't bother most people but i get claustophobic, so it was a bit of a shock, the nurses did their best to uncover me and the doctor cracked jokes and told funny stories whilst working, bless him, so that helped. Now the anesthetic is wearing off!!!!! hopefully it will feel better tomorrow. But at least i will not feel like a pin cushion from now on. take care everyone, i get my 2nd chemo tomorrow, hopefully i will not be in the hospital for so long this time.
Posts.Title: hickman line fitted by comedien

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, did you see your plastic surgeon in February.  I hope you are well and if you've had the op that you are wel on the mend. What reconstruction did you go for?  What stage are you at now? I'm still undecided what to have, tram flap of latissimus dorsi flap.  can't stop thinking about the bloomin op.  At least when i had my mastectomy, i only had 24 hours to think about it. Keep positive, hope you are OK. Jules
Posts.Title: what reconstruction to have

Posts.Content: Hi How are you doing? has the implant been put in yet? My doctor said if i had LD flap then i would probably need implant under the muscle as my right breast is a d cup.  I'm still so undecided about whether to have LD Flap or TRAM Flap..........so many pros and cons. At least with the mastectomy i only had 24 hours to think about it and then had it done.  I do hope you're feeling ok and if you've had the op, are soon up and about.
Posts.Title: what reconstruction to have

Posts.Content: I've been to see the consultant who will conduct the plastic surgery for my new breast today.  He told me i can't have an implant as i have had radiotherapy, but to be honest i didn't want an implant anyway. My choices are Tram flap ( tissue and muscle taken from my tummy ) he kindly said there was just about enough of it.  Or the Latissimus Dorsi flap, the muscle and tissue tunneled from the back to make a new breast. Has anyone had either of these ops, and would you mind telling me in detail what it really feels like afterwards.  I have read on the macmillan website that the breast will feel numb, but no one seems to say what it feels like when walking or moving about, within the body does it move like a normal breast and feel like a normal breast.  Hope this makes sense but as the surgeon is a man i didn't think he would know. Any help would be appreciated, i have decided not to have the op until next year, so i have plenty of time to gather information and make a decision. Jules49
Posts.Title: what reconstruction to have

Posts.Content: Thanks Lorna1, for your reply.  Did your doctor advise you about the pros and cons of this op.  He said he was out of the information leaflets when i was at the hospital but that he would send one thro the post later. Where are the drains? and can you lie on your back while in hospital? I know what you mean about keeping regular, haha, had that problem after mastectomy. I would be grateful if you post regularly over coming weeks/months. that would be really helpful.   I hope you are feeling better each day and are soon back to your normal routine. Thanks again jules49
Posts.Title: what reconstruction to have

Posts.Content: I had radiotherapy on my left side after a mastectomy and my arm pit after the lymph nodes were removed in 2011. I recently went on holiday and sunbathed a total of few hours every day but mainly stayed in the shade.  i have got a tan but did not burn or blister just lovely brown. On returning, under my arm where the axillery scar is is hurting now.  I don't know if this is due to the sun changing the cells and the previous radiotherapy or if its because i was wearing bathing wear and not my usual bra for 11 days. Has this happened to anyone else?
Posts.Title: sunbathing after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi, everyone, hope you are all keeping strong and looking forward to the festive season.  Well, me and my beloved husband did get away for our silver wedding anniversary, a tour of Jordan.  It was hard work for me as I had just finished chemo treatment and i was in bed by 9.30 every night, but we did enjoy it, had a fantastic time and met some really nice people. The day after we arrived home i started my Radiotherapy and it is going OK so far, only two to go on monday and tuesday.  The 50 miles round trip seems to be tiring us out, i have to take a travel sickness tablet every day because they move the bed around so much with me on it.  my skin has gone a little red but i can still wear the bra and get out christmas shopping. I am feeling very positive at the moment.  Thinking of returning to work in the new year and celebrating my 50th birthday.  I have decided that leisure time is going to be punctuated with work and not work punctuated with leisure from now on................my friends, bless them are arranging a weekend away with me too. I do hope everyone else with this terrible cronic illness is doing fine, at whatever stage of treatment you are and have a very merry christmas and healthy new year. Jules
Posts.Title: I've been neglecting to log on

Posts.Content: Hi, i found your remarks really helpful.  I have just had one lot of FEC and my head was very sore two days ago, now my hair is falling out in handfuls.  I'm a bit like you been a clean freak, i wish it would all go by tomorrow then i could tick it off the list and stop finding hair on the furniture. i collected my wig today, it's looks great, just like stepping out of the hairdressers. I was wondering how soon after the treatment the hair would grow back, or even if it would mid way through the treatment as they change the drugs on the 4th.  I see yours did grow back sooner rather than later - i must admit everyone i've seen at the clinic so far have their hair so it gives me hope the baldness will not last too long.
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Just to give everyone my thoughts at the moment, I have had mastectomy and axilliary clearance ops within a month and so still feel tired and sore.  But on the positive side all cancer cells have been removed, the numbness in my upper arm has gone and no ' cording' up to now.  The cold does affect my scar areas,when i shiver it hurts. Going for a walk in the beautiful country side just outside my door helps and the physio exercises help alot.  The boredom has set in as i normally work long shifts.  I have watched more DVD's than i can remember and The Eurovision song contest did cheer me up! I am waiting for an appointment with the oncologist as chemo and RT needed.  Has anyone had these treatments and returned to work during the treatment, I have heard of one person locally who did this and wondered if it is possible.  We have a special trip booked for November for our silver wedding anniversary and so we are aiming for that to keep our chins up. All the comments on this forum are helpful and informative thank you to everyone so far.  I am sure I will be here again with more updates - good ones I hope.
Posts.Title: feeling positive

Posts.Content: glad to hear your experience was a good one.  Mine was too.  Keep taking something to stop constipation as the anti sickness drugs will catch up with your system,  i suffered because of it!!  I had the sneezy feeling in my nose too and the cold arm.  My treatment finished last october and the mild side effects lasted until last month as the oncologist said they would.  It wasn't as bad experience as i had thought and certainly worth it if it stops the cancer coming back. good luck with the rest of your treatment.................keep positive
Posts.Title: A good FEC experience!

Posts.Content: Hi, i haven't logged on to this web site for a while and quickly saw your comment.  Briefly I had a mastectomy April 2011 and finished treatment by Dec that year.  I returned to work 2012 and also visited a plastic surgeon.  He explained the procedure for tram flap ( where tissue is taken from the tummy and used to reconstruct a breast ) and the dorsal where the muscle from under your should blade is pushed through to the front and makes the shape of a breast.  After six months of discussions with the surgeon, and other medical exerts i decided to go for the tram flap as it gives the best final results. I had the reconstruction in March this year, the procedure is a long one and it was rough at times, but WOW, i can't tell you what its done for my confidence.  Everyone remarks how good i look, thats because i feel like a sexy woman again.  sorry to get personal but my sex life has improved too because of the way i feel.  God bless the NHS. I am to return to hospital next year to have the right breast reduced and a few fillers added to the left lside by using lyposuction on my hips.  so all in all i will have two younger looking breasts, feel better about myself, flatter tummy and no fat on my hips.  Its a win win situation. I wish you luck in making your decision, I encourage you to discuss every little detail with the surgical team.  My surgeon is very approachable and patient, he is honest but does his best to give me what i want.  The next time i see him we'll be discussing what kind of nipples i want, so it does get a bit bizaare but it's his work and my body so we both work together to get the best result. Take care and I hope everything goes OK for you.
Posts.Title: Recent reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi, just read that your next hurdle is radiotherapy/hormones.  Do you have your appointments yet.  I had radiotherapy after chemo, started last November.  I was determined to go on a special holiday to Jordan after chemo and so the day after i returned from hols i started 15 days of RT.  I get motion sickness and the worse thing about the treatment was i had to lie down flat and they kept moving the table about, just a few cms so i had to take a travel sickness tablet every day to stop the motion sickness.  My skin did not change much after the RT, it was red as though i had sunburn on it, but it has faded now..  i was tired afterwards, but i think that was because it was a 50 miles round trip every day for 15 days.  some people on this forum have said they go to work and call in for their treatment at lunch time!! brilliant if you can. Be kind to yourself, your body has been through alot.  I had my op april 2011. chemo started june 2011 until sept and RT in nov.  i returned to work on reduced hours april 2012 and i;m still only working 5hrs a day.  i enjoy every single moment now.  i know it sounds strange but having BC and surviving has gave me a new lease of life...........i'm defo positive about the future. the best of luck to you.  hope the treatment goes well and that return to 'normal' soon.
Posts.Title: Living again

Posts.Content: Hi , i know you wrote your message a while ago.  I hope you are well and feeling ok after your treatment. I can understand how you felt at 40 yrs old, but my mum went through menopause at 42, it took 18 months and she always said she felt much better afterwards, and didn;t have the worry of unwanted pregnancy.  so there are positive sides to it. I;m 50 and had been on the contraceptive pill which i took everyday and so had not had a period for 3 years, of course i had to stop taking the pill as soon as i was diagnosed.  i started chemo in june 2011 had a period in the june and july and haven't had one since.  to me it's the good side of the treatment.  i only get a warm (not hot ) flush every evening which reminds me to take my tamoxifen tablet before i go to bed.  i feel great. Hope you keep well and positive. take care
Posts.Title: Periods during chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, i totally understand where you are coming from, when you are out in a restaurant and find yourself thinking. ' you don't know what i look like under these clothes'. But I have found other ways to shine.  I was never one to do my hair but now i get it done every month. people always comment on how nice it looks.  i have changed my make up and toiletries to organic. my skin has improved no end.  i'm still struggling with the eating healthy mylarky. I have my nails done and go for a massage anything to lift my spirits.  talk to your friends and family about it, tell them how you feel and ask them to cheer you up.  giving them something positive to do for you may be all they are waiting to hear. i am a d cup, and asked for reconstruction at the same time as MX, and it was not recommended, as radiotherapy alters the skin and tissue so much, my GP said he has had loads of patients come back to him with disformed reconstructed breasts, which needed to be removed and start again. I had mx april 2011.  I plan to have Tram flap in Feb 2013.  i am not allowed implants on the NHS because of the radiotherapy. the nhs surgeon said i would be able to get a private clinic to do it, but he would not recommend it. I think you may need to speak to your breast care nurse about getting therapy, talking to someone about how you feel, before you go for reconstruction.  Ask the hospital if they have a dvd of women who have had the op, see what they look like without clothes on.  the dvd i saw was excellent from Newcastle General.  i darn't get too excited about the result, the surgeon says it is to give me a breast shape under clothes, so it will not be perfect when i am naked.  my husband doesn't mind. you don't say if you have a partner.  i think its a confidence thing and can be changed so don't be downhearted every day, ask for help and talk, talk talk, do something positive about it and don't let the cancer win. be positive jules
Posts.Title: Does it stay llike this?

Posts.Content: Hi, I have read about the way your condition is being treated and find it interesting if not a bit confusing. I had a 73mm tumour grade 2 invasive ductal cancer with lobular like growths in the left breast and was advised mastectomy was the best option, then pre cancerous cells were found in two of the lymph nodes, so a second op was needed to remove all the lymph nodes. luckily no other cancer cells were found. I was then advised to have 6 x Fec-t and radiotherapy.  they still await the results to confirm if i am HER2 Positive or HER2 Negative so not sure which hormonal treatment is needed. The BCN always says the chemo and RT are insurance policies against the cancer returning.  and from what i have read on numerous UK and USA web sites i agree and am happy to receive the treatment.  i know there are side affects short and long term, but feel chemo does the trick.  if one cell in my body is even thinking of changing then i want it to be dead and gone.  many many women i know have had exactly the same treatment as myself and are here to tell their story 10 20 and 40 years later. so i say bring on the treatment. all i can advise you is to check again with your health care workers, but also do some independant investigation yourself and of course you have started by asking here for others thoughts.  i am not sure if all this has helped but hope you find information you are searching for and feel more confident about the treatment soon.
Posts.Title: Concerns about chemo

Posts.Content: my advise is to keep looking forward to your hols for as long as possible and don't cancel, but always stay flexible.  i had mastectomy in april and unfortunately had to go back in may to have lymph nodes removed.  then on the first day of chemo treatment my veins were so bad i had to have hickman line fitted and could not travel out of UK, or very far with it..........don't mean to alarm you but you never know what is going to happen and march is long way off.........no doctor or nurse stopped me from going on hols but circumstances meant i had to cancel and re book...........there will be plenty of other times to go on hols.
Posts.Title: travel insurance

Posts.Content: Just seen your post..........if you're looking for insurance with a pre known medical condition I go for 'allclear' although they don't cover annual insurance only for one trip at a time. hope this helps
Posts.Title: travel insurance

Posts.Content: Americagirl - thank goodness your results are back, i know the waiting and worrying is terrible.  I had a mastectomy and lymph nodes removed.  2 out of 12 nodes had pre cancerous cells within.  I am receiving 6 sessions of FEC-T chemo and 15 sessions of radiotherapy.  I have had my fourth chemo session.  The first FEC made me feel sick so the hospital gave stronger anti sickness tablets and i haveen't felt sick again. but the anti sickness tablets made me constipated, Get something for this before it happens - it will save you alot of discomfort and you can always 'tweek' the dose until it works for you.  The last three sessions of T Chemo do not cause sickness, therefore no anti sickness tables were given therefore no more constipation. my general advice would be stock up with all medicines and help for the side affects and then you will be prepared before they hit too bad.  i have not been able to return to work as yet but find that two weeks out of the three i can get out and about, go shopping, for meals out, visit friends and go to the theatre just rest when you need it and let anyone help you do those house hold chores you don't like!!!!! even if you can do them.  good luck
Posts.Title: Surgery results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi, I don't know about anyone else, but as soon as i set foot in to the hospital my memory goes.  I visited the oncologist today and meant to ask if i can now use blonde hair dye as it has been 9 months since my chemo finished.  but i forgot!!! does anyone out there have any advice from their doctor/onclogist. i know brown hair dye is different and blonde is more risky because of the bleaching agent, but i am getting a bit tired of being the grey lady.   thank you take care
Posts.Title: CHANGING HAIR COLOUR FROM GREY TO BLONDE AFTER CHEMO?

Posts.Content: Hi margr20 I had chemo for breast cancer three years ago. for 6 months i covered up with cotton clothes and put factor 50 on hands and face. 6 - 12 months i still used high factor sun screen ( which we all should do anyway) and sat in sun for 10 mins then in the shade for 2 hours. Only two years after treatment did i sit with legs in the sun and face but still kept my neck, chest and left arm/shoulder covered. a walk along the beach each morning and afternoon was the only time those bits were exposed to sunlight.  i managed to get a lovely golden tan - still using the factor 50.  and no swelling or burning the oncologist and surgeon have not mentioned anything about my suntan last time i saw them. and they saw my white bits! take it very slow - its not worth it. keep safe juliex49
Posts.Title: SUNSHINE!

Posts.Content: Hi Janet59, i have not started my RT yet, but thought that the department would be able to play piped music to you, try asking them if its available, you never know it may help I do hope so.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: First radiotherapy treatment

Posts.Content: Hi, i was first diagnosed in March, had a mastectomy in April and Axillary clearance to take the lymph nodes away in may.  My chemo started in June, and i have had my 2nd lot out of 6 FEC-T. I slept last night for the first time with no hair, and i have to say it was a bit chilly.  I decided against cold cap treatment, how about you?  I have loads of nice scarves and my wig for best.  I was pleasantly surprised to hear lots of ladies hair grow back before the end of chemo, but i'll not count my chickens just yet, as long as it starts to come back for the winter. Take care, hope you are still feeling OK. Jules
Posts.Title: hair falling out

Posts.Content: Hi mjangelfairy - my scalp started to tingle at day 15 and the hair started to shed at day 17.  over the next few days lots of shedding happened, i decided to comb my hair in the garden so as not to get it all over the house!!  It continued to fall out for about a week, but i still had lots of it.  after my 2nd chemo most of it came out on day 5 and today i have cut the rest off myself.  my scalp is still a bit 'fluffy' but i'm sure this will come out in the shower over the next few days. I am glad to hear you have not had too many side effects, lets hope it stays like that all the way through, keep strong jules49
Posts.Title: hair falling out

Posts.Content: I have just read your discussion and found the information very helpful.  I have just finished radiotherapy.  me and my partner have not had sex for some months now, but would like to start again.  i was worried about dryness and have only KY Jelly at the moment, i will ask the oncolgist tomorrow as i was told to keep well clear of anything with eastrogen and so we have to use condoms. thanks again.
Posts.Title: Tried to have intercourse, sooo painful

Posts.Content: Hi caz1965 - you are a bit further down the line with your treatment than me.  But i know what you mean about feeling low and insecure, i do too sometimes.  but i try to see the beautiful things in life, even if its just a bit of blue sky one day.  i have decided not to be hard on myself and to be grateful for being here to enjoy the good things.  i had a meal out with friends on tuesday and can honestly say i felt 'normal' all night and didn't even think of my condition, or my wig which is normally always at the back of my mind.  I know its difficult but nothing lasts forever, and i'm sure with the support of family and friends you'll come out the other side feeling more confident than before.  take it easy.   julies49
Posts.Title: low confidence help

Posts.Content: Has anyone elses family experienced guilty feelings.  I was diagnosed with breast cancer in march 2011.  thankfully surgery removed it completely and i have just completed chemo.  my sister who is ten years older than me found it very difficult to deal with the situation and says the doctor has given her tablets but will not discuss what they are.  she is behaving strangely and has mood swings when she visits me and i would like to help and understand her more.  back in march she took to mothering me at first and calling me 'baby' which i found strange.  then she cried at every visit, and now when i tell her of my chemo side affects she states she is getting the same problems!! what is going on? has anyone else experienced strange affects of their diagnosis on their relatives.  i feel i am quite positive about my condition and basically i get on with it, but my sister finds it impossible to do, she has an unhappy home life where as mine is great and my husband is my friend so i don't know if its guilt or her being jealous of the support i am getting.  jules49
Posts.Title: sister is so guilty about cancer

Posts.Content: thanks janique for your reply.  She is depressed, and has said she is on tablets but won't say what they are.  our mother died last year and she is still feeling the after affects from that, i am too, of course but have a better support network than my sister.  i have suggested she come on to this forum herself as i find it so helpful. my sister called last evening to say she is in financial difficultly, i suggested several ways of resolving the matter which she is going to think of.  i will try to support her a little, but feel unable to get totally involved myself as i have problems too.  i have suggested she speak to professionals about the matter. thanks for your reply it helps to have someone take a step back from the situation and see it clearly.
Posts.Title: sister is so guilty about cancer
